title: Tuesday, 1st May, 2018

Mike was composing himself between interviews. As many of us do, he was singing songs to himself to clear his mind. He recently saw 42nd Street, where this song is from and we all know these songs stay in your head. To attach any wider meaning to this innocent, personal moment is preposterous.

nichoman Its a bit of an unfortunate choice of song but I think we should cut the guy some slack - maybe he was singing it to his kids and the tune just stuck in his head. Or some media trainer has told him to sing it to himself to calm himself for interviews.

cracklenpop @Badger shades of Norman Lamont singing in the bath after sterling left the ERM

Was talking about this with a Feltcollaredsource last night, who suggested they should've just leaned into it. Quick cut a Sainsbury advert using the tune.

And it seems we've lost Bruno at Bernstein to "Team It Ain't Going to Happen".

BE11:09am

It is indeed about: 'will CMA include discounters'? But our view on CMA methodology was out of date. Recent rulings (Coral, Tesco-Booker) may have been about very different markets, but some principles were established. One of those is the concept of 'weighted share of shops'. In the past CMA work, a store was either a competitor or not; very binary. Now many more competitors are considered, but they may be allocated lower weightings. This implies that discounters, small convenience stores and even online retail will be considered competitors, but probably with lower weightings. Those extra competitors in the consideration set, can materially impact the number of store disposals. The Tesco Booker deal did acknowledge that discounters are now part of the consideration set. This improves materially the odds of the deal going through without very punitive disposal terms.

Post Asda-SBRY proposed merger, we see risk of UK competition stepping up in the interim. We downgrade to Neutral from Buy. Capital Framework still suggests cashback to shareholders, but amount could be at risk if there's more competition. Current 19E lease adj. EV/EBITDAR of 7.4x, a 5.5% sector premium sufficiently accounts for the upside and downside risks.

For us, the key takeaway from yesterday’s Asda/Sainsbury’s announcement was the pressure they are facing from the discounters and online, squeezing margins. As a result, they are promising further price competition, which could squeeze industry margins further. However, this distraction (intrinsic in the M&A but also via heightened competition) should provide a boost for Ocado, allowing it to take advantage as the legacy players continue to fight for the survival of their offline offering in a world where everything is going online.

BE11:26am

JE reiterated its guidance which implies that revenue growth will slow to 13-22% for the remainder of the year – unlikely in our view. We calculate that the main part of the beat came from logistics, but the marketplace in the UK and ROW were also better, despite headwind in Australia. The core UK marketplace delivered 17% underlying organic order growth and we estimate revenue growth close to 20% - this shows that the secular growth in mature regions continues to be higher than the market gives it credit for. JE continues to trade at a large discount to its peer group, although some of these vendors have depressed profits. Such a discount is becoming increasingly difficult to justify, in our view, given its accelerating growth profile. CMD on 27 June could be the next positive catalyst.

Q1’18 was outstanding. Revenue of $297.3m was +284% YoY and EBITDA of $237.3m was +418% YoY. New customers of 72,960 were +228% and Active customers +204% to 218,187. When coupled with a 26% YoY increase in ARPU, to $1,363 and a 45% reduction in AUAC, the result was a record performance. We have increased our ARPU assumption for CY18 by 3% to $1,654, which in turn drives a 4% increase to CY18 EPS. This is cautious.

#REF! @soundbuy problems with 'adjusted' figures. The accounting standards have rules, but often valuations done on adjusted figures. One can choose whatever adjustments you want, not auditors job to commentThis is where analysts and institutions should pressure companies (see the recent alphaville post)

It would appear that because a large proportion of the new customers joined late into the quarter, churn -- Q4 2017: 23% -- and average revenue per user -- Q4 2017: $591 -- were depressed. Both metrics have normalised in Q1, with average revenue per user increasing to $1,363 (Q1-Q3 2017 average: $1,230) and churn increasing to 35%. As the costs associated with the new customers were expensed in Q4 2017, customer acquisition costs remain low at $502 so the spread between revenues and costs increased the EBITDA margin to an all-time high of 80% (FY 2017: 55%).

Despite a stunning quarter, we do not extrapolate
the performance in the first quarter into the rest of the year as there remains much uncertainty about both the impact of EMSA’s intervention measures and the eventual run-rate of active customers. We have therefore only increased our FY 2018 revenue estimate to $577m and EBITDA to $329m. If Plus500 can navigate the current regulatory environment, we think there is scope for upgrades in the future.

BE11:48am

Think it's a beat though. Here's the quick summary from the excellent Christyan Malek at JP Morgan.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

BP reported clean 1Q earnings of $2,586m, 17% ahead of consensus $2,210m; CFFO
ex-WC and pre-Macondo of $7.1bn screens strongly against market expectations of ~$6.5bn (JPMe top end at $7.7bn). 1) Upstream. BP's highest divisional result for 3 years was underpinned by strong operational efficiency through project ramp-ups as well as higher realisations as flagged in our 1Q Best Ideas BP. Underlying production ex-Rosneft 2.6mboe/d represents a sixth consecutive quarter of growth and is +13.8% y/y; 2) Downstream. A strong result saw BP mitigate lower headline refining margins through differentiated exposure to wider NAM L-H spreads (as highlighted in our Refining 'Silver Age' report) and lower q/q turnarounds/costs; 3) Capex. Lower capex of $3.5bn compares to JPMe $3.9bn (we are at the low end of consensus for 2018: $15.5bn) and implies an annual run-rate of $14bn vs. the company range which has been reiterated at $15-16bn in 2018. ; 4) Gearing and Macondo. Remained broadly flat q/q at 28.1% ND/CE due to a $1.7bn WC build (a recurring theme across the group for 1Q) and previously guided front-end loading to 2018 Macondo outflows ($1.7bn of FY guidance just over $3bn).

Soundbuy DS Smith +2.9% on update, passing on costs, would usually read across to Smurfit......but....
wayneJ @Groucho - one of my favourite quotes
BE11:48am

And Barclays.

BE11:49am

Earnings were 17% ahead of company compiled consensus with beats at both in both the upstream and the downstream reflecting both strong operational performance in the upstream and what appears good capture of the differentials in the downstream. This is the fifth consecutive quarter that BP has delivered a beat to consensus expectations and highlights to us that the market does not appear to fully reflect the improvement in the portfolio in estimates as yet. The underlying cash break-even number in the quarter of $42/bl reflects cash from operations 9% ahead of estimates. Gearing was up, as expected given the timing mismatch between the Macondo payments and divestment proceeds. The only slight negative we can see is that at $120m share buybacks in the quarter the pace is running below that needed to offset the scrip dilution. However with the focus on deleveraging the near term priority this likely reflects the Macondo payments timing and we would expect management to address this on the call. We rate the stock Overweight with a 675p price target.

BE11:54am

Johnston Press recently reported FY17 results that were broadly in line with market expectations but the highlight was the performance of the “I” national newspaper. Q1 has traded in line with expectations with the company suggesting adj. EBITDA is higher than the previous year. The performance of the “I” continues to be strong in 2018 with its revenues being up 21% yoy in Q1. However, the trading environment remains tough and with comparatives getting tougher we do not expect consensus estimates to change at this stage. Management is focused on putting through further revenue and cost synergies to protect margins. Examples include the content content sharing synergies with the Group that include centrally coordinated investigative features and news along side other National titles.

In conducting the strategic review, Vista Outdoor management defined several criteria to evaluate whether individual product categories are part of the company's core. Vista Outdoor evaluated brands within its current portfolio based on their ability to do the following:

Serve the company's target consumer – the outdoor enthusiast
Create cross-selling and other similar synergy opportunities
Achieve market leading positions and leadership economics
Demonstrate omni-channel distribution capabilities
